AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a distinctively soft foliage with a nice pyramidal shape
2-3” long, flat, soft, silvery blue-green, upward-curved needles; 2 bands of stomata below
smooth and gray on young trees, becoming ashy-gray and furrowed in older trees
catkin-like yellow to red males; females are yellow-brown and inconspicuous
3-5” long cones sit upright on branches; yellow-green to purple in color

The Concolor or White Fir is an attractive conifer that can be used either in home landscaping or as a decorative Christmas tree. With silvery blue-green needles, it makes an ideal accent plant. It also provides an alternative for the disease and insect prone Colorado Blue Spruce. The Concolor Fir is native to mountainous regions of the western United States. In the west, this tree is referred to as the Rocky Mountain White Fir. Because of its nearly perfect pyramidal shape, the Concolor Fir makes a pleasing landscape tree with a variety of applications. Because of its lighter colored needles, this tree is often used to contrast darker colored evergreens. As with all Fir trees, the Concolor Fir holds its long cones characteristically upright. This moderately rapid growing tree will grow up to 50 feet in height or more, while some specimens have grown to more than 100 feet tall. It has a moderately long life span, with individual trees occasionally living up to 350 years. Preferring a moist, rich soil, the Concolor Fir will not tolerate poorly drained soils well. The Concolor Fir is the most drought resistant and salt tolerant of all the fir trees. It likes full sun but will tolerate some shade. The younger Concolor Fir tree has a tendency to develop multiple leaders, so pruning may be required to produce a central leader. As the tree ages, its dense growth eliminates the need for pruning to retain its conical shape. As a Christmas tree, the Concolor Fir is one of the longest needle firs and is sometimes mistaken for a pine. The needle has a pleasant fragrance when broken; the aroma has been compared to a citrus or tangerine likeness. The Concolor Fir Christmas tree retains its needles for several weeks. Most of these Christmas trees find their home in California. The wood of the Concolor Fir is soft and knotty. It is used occasionally for papermaking or in cheap construction. Two stately Concolor Firs are placed prominently on either side of the main entrance to Somsen Hall on the north side of WSU’s main administration building. Another younger Concolor Fir is located just south west of the main entrance to Maxwell Hall.
